message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary prevention refers to actions taken to prevent onset of disease or injury before it occurs, such as reducing intake of trans fats to lower the risk of coronary artery disease. Secondary prevention refers to actions taken to detect and treat an existing disease or injury before it becomes symptomatic or life-threatening, while tertiary prevention refers to actions taken to prevent further disability or impairment in individuals with already established disease. Delayed prevention is not a recognized term in preventive medicine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary prevention refers to actions taken to prevent the development of disease in individuals who are at risk. In this case, the patient is making dietary changes to reduce his risk of developing heart disease, which falls under primary prevention. Secondary prevention refers to early detection and intervention in an effort to prevent the progression of disease, while tertiary prevention refers to the management of established disease to prevent complications. Delayed prevention is not a recognized term in medicine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary prevention aims to prevent the development of a disease in a patient who has not yet developed the disease, such as lifestyle changes to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease. Secondary prevention aims to prevent the progression of an existing disease, while tertiary prevention aims to reduce the complications of a disease that has already occurred. Delayed prevention is not a recognized term in medical prevention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary prevention refers to interventions that prevent the occurrence of a disease or injury before it occurs. In this case, the patient is taking steps to reduce his risk of developing coronary artery disease by decreasing his intake of trans fats. This is an example of primary prevention. Secondary prevention refers to detecting and treating a disease early to prevent complications, while tertiary prevention refers to managing and treating existing disease to prevent further complications. Delayed prevention is not a recognized term in medicine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary prevention refers to actions taken to prevent the development of a disease or condition in individuals who do not have that disease or condition. In this case, the patient is taking steps to reduce his risk of developing coronary artery disease by decreasing his intake of trans fats, which is an example of primary prevention. Secondary prevention refers to actions taken to detect and treat a disease in its early stages, while tertiary prevention refers to actions taken to prevent complications and manage the effects of a disease or condition that has already been diagnosed. Delayed prevention is not a recognized term in medical practice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary prevention focuses on preventing the onset of a disease or condition. In this case, the patient is taking steps to reduce his risk of heart disease before he develops the condition, making it an example of primary prevention. Secondary prevention involves detecting and treating a condition in its early stages, while tertiary prevention focuses on managing and treating an existing disease or condition to prevent complications. Delayed prevention is not a recognized term in the field of medicine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is taking steps to prevent the development of heart disease, which is the aim of primary prevention. Secondary prevention focuses on early detection and treatment of existing conditions, while tertiary prevention aims to prevent complications and worsening of existing disease. Delayed prevention is not a recognized term in the field of medicine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary prevention aims to prevent the development of a disease or injury. In this scenario, the patient is trying to lower his risk of coronary artery disease by making a lifestyle change, thus fitting into the category of primary prevention. Secondary prevention aims to detect and treat a disease in its early stages, while tertiary prevention aims to manage and slow the progression of a disease. Delayed prevention is not a recognized category of prevention in medical practice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary prevention aims to prevent the onset of disease by addressing risk factors before the disease occurs. In this scenario, the patient is taking steps to reduce his risk of developing coronary artery disease, which is a form of primary prevention. Secondary prevention aims to detect and treat early stages of disease before it progresses, while tertiary prevention focuses on preventing complications and further deterioration of established disease. Delayed prevention is not a recognized term in medicine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Primary prevention involves actions taken to prevent the development of a disease in people who have never had the disease before. In this case, the patient is trying to decrease his intake of trans fats in order to prevent the development of coronary artery disease, thus this is an example of primary prevention.
